author: By Nicholas Casey
title: The Cop Was the Hero in One Viral Video. Another Told a Different Story.
description: Bobby White was celebrated as the “Basketball Cop” after millions saw a video of him shooting hoops with local teenagers. A recording from two years earlier shows him throwing a young Black man on the hood of his car during an arrest.
content: Aahtrell Johnson remembered the police car rolling up, just before he was about to take his shot at the basket under the pine trees. It was 2016, and his neighbor had called 911, complaining that he was getting loud in the street. A white officer named Bobby White had been sent to respond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Campaign Makes Huge Digital Ad Buy During Democratic Convention
description: The Trump campaign is trying to make sure that Mr. Trump’s message will be almost impossible to miss even during the Democrats’ biggest week.
content: The Trump campaign is launching an aggressive four-day digital advertising campaign that will take over some of the internet’s most conspicuous real estate during the three marquee days of the Democratic National Convention, which most viewers will watch online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Pelicans Fire Coach Alvin Gentry
description: After leaving the N.B.A. bubble in Florida with two wins in eight games, New Orleans announced that it would look for a new coach before Zion Williamson’s second season.
content: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Zion Williamson, the Pelicans’ cornerstone forward, will have a new coach in New Orleans next season as he tries to rebound from an injury-plagued rookie season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger and Ronen Bergman
title: Shifting Dynamics of the Mideast Pushed Israel and U.A.E. Together
description: Prime Minister Netanyahu’s quest to open relations with Arab countries without settling the Palestinian conflict long seemed quixotic. External events changed the equation.
content: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu buoyantly approached the microphone, beaming at his diplomatic coup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly DiNardo
title: Sneak In Some Exercise
description: Yes, we are moving less. But on Zoom, no one has to know you’re doing squats.
content: There’s a reason “Covid curves” and “the Quarantine 15” are now commonplace terms. While researchers are beginning to look at the connection between the pandemic and weight gain, it’s apparent that we’re moving less during this topsy-turvy period: A preliminary study published in May and led by Iowa State University and Trinity College Dublin reported an average 32 percent reduction in physical activity once social distancing went into effect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Schram
title: Recreating Home Ice, Far From Home
description: N.H.L. teams’ raucous home arena traditions have persisted, with tweaks, in the postseason hub cities.
content: EDMONTON — In any other year, they would be waging battle in the Fortress, the nickname for T-Mobile Arena, where the Vegas Golden Knights notoriously defend home ice to the tune of a 75-33-11 record over three seasons, fifth-best in the N.H.L.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni and Ernesto Londoño
title: Coronavirus Crisis Has Made Brazil an Ideal Vaccine Laboratory
description: Widespread contagion, a deep bench of scientists and a robust vaccine-making infrastructure have made Brazil an important player in the quest to find a vaccine.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — The chaotic response to the coronavirus in Brazil, where it has killed more than 105,000 people, made the country’s experience a cautionary tale that many around the world have watched with alarm.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Quietly, Greece Casts Refugees Adrift in Rafts
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 15, 2020.
content: “I left Syria for fear of bombing — but when this happened, I wished I’d died under a bomb.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Associated Press
title: Bruins Goaltender Tuukka Rask Is Biggest N.H.L. Name to Opt Out
description: Rask led the league with a 2.12 goals against average this season, but Boston had won just one of five games in the postseason when the goalie made the announcement.
content: Boston Bruins goalie Tuukka Rask has opted out of the team’s playoff run to be with his family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma
title: ‘We’re Desperate’: Transit Cuts Felt Deepest in Low-Income Areas
description: As the pandemic wreaks havoc on public transit systems across the country, experts say it is low-income residents, people of color and essential workers bearing the brunt.
content: WASHINGTON — As Nina Red stood under a tree in the New Orleans rain, waiting for two buses that never came, she recalled a feeling of helplessness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naomi Huffman
title: The Radical Ordinariness of Carol Shields’s Literary World
description: The acclaimed novelist and story writer, who died in 2003, depicted the everyday experiences and domestic concerns of women — themes that deserve more literary recognition.
content: When Carol Shields died of breast cancer in 2003, her obituary in The New York Times remembered her as a novelist whose work highlighted the “profundity of the mundane,” while The Guardian mentioned her “commitment to commemorating otherwise ordinary lives.” Shields specialized in fiction devoted to women characters and their experience; nearly two decades later, the province of “ordinary” women in fiction still needs defending. Earlier this year, a generously endowed new literary prize for women writers was announced in Shields’s name — a choice made in part, one of the award’s founders explained, to underscore the value of domestic concerns in literature, which too often have been considered unworthy of serious fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Japanese Politicians Mark War Anniversary at Contentious Shrine
description: Shinjiro Koizumi, a rising political star, was one of four cabinet ministers who went to Yasukuni Shrine, which has strong links to Japan’s imperial past.
content: TOKYO — Four Japanese cabinet ministers, including a rising political star seen as a potential prime minister, marked the 75th anniversary of World War II’s end on Saturday by visiting Yasukuni Shrine, a memorial with strong links to Japan’s imperial past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Astead W. Herndon
title: Kamala Harris Changes the Race While Trump Tells on Himself
description: There were surprises this week that weren’t entirely shocking: Ms. Harris joined Joe Biden’s ticket and President Trump resurrected birtherism. Here’s what to make of the last week in politics.
content: Welcome to our weekly analysis of the state of the 2020 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: As Colleges Move Classes Online, Families Rebel Against the Cost
description: Schools face rising demands for tuition rebates, increased aid and leaves of absence as students ask if college is becoming “glorified Skype.”
content: After Southern California’s soaring coronavirus caseload forced Chapman University this month to abruptly abandon plans to reopen its campus and shift to an autumn of all-remote instruction, the school promised that students would still get a “robust Chapman experience.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: ‘We’re Clearly Not Doing Enough’: Drop in Testing Hampers Coronavirus Response
description: For the first time during the pandemic, the United States saw a downward trend in the number of coronavirus tests conducted each day.
content: For months, public health experts and federal officials have said that significantly expanding the number of coronavirus tests administered in the United States is essential to reining in the pandemic. By some estimates, several million people might need to be tested each day, including many people who don’t feel sick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: Mothers, Babies Stranded in Ukraine Surrogacy Industry
description: Virus travel bans are wreaking havoc on surrogacy agencies that help same-sex couples build families.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Tears streamed down Yevhenia Troyan’s face as her flight took off from Northern Cyprus, one of the odd corners of Europe where Ukrainian surrogacy agencies have set up shop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: As Relations With U.S. Sink, China Tones Down ‘Hotheaded’ Nationalism
description: Beijing is dialing down its belligerence to avoid provocative moves that might give President Trump more opportunities to attack ahead of the November election.
content: For weeks, China fanned nationalist sentiment in its escalating war of words with the Trump administration. Now, it is toning down its message and calling for a truce, as President Trump increasingly makes Beijing a target in his bid for re-election in November.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Birtherism Redux: Trump Raises Questions About Kamala Harris
description: Readers condemn the president’s false suggestion that Ms. Harris might not be eligible to run for vice president because her parents were immigrants.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Warzel
title: The Week QAnon Went Mainstream
description: A supporter of the dangerous conspiracy theory is most likely headed to Congress. The social media platforms have some soul-searching to do.
content: For almost three years, I’ve wondered when the QAnon tipping point would arrive — the time when a critical mass of Americans would come to regard the sprawling pro-Trump conspiracy theory not merely as a sideshow, but as a legitimate threat to safety and even democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson and Marie Fazio
title: 3 Mississippi Police Officers Charged With Murder of Black Man
description: A grand jury indictment accused the officers of pulling George Robinson, 62, from his car in Jackson, Miss., last year, slamming him headfirst into the pavement, and striking and kicking him in the head and the chest.
content: Three Mississippi police officers have been charged with killing a Black man by body-slamming him to the ground and then beating him last year, the authorities said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba
title: Viral falsehoods about Kamala Harris have surged since she joined the Biden ticket.
description: As Joseph R. Biden Jr. announced that he had selected Kamala Harris of California as his vice-presidential running mate, internet trolls got to work.
content: As Joseph R. Biden Jr. announced that he had selected Kamala Harris of California as his vice-presidential running mate, internet trolls got to work.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Broccoli Salad Recipe to Believe In
description: Make Lidey Heuck’s recipe, or get ambitious with an eggplant focaccia.
content: That’s how one reader described our most popular recipe this week, Lidey Heuck’s broccoli salad with peanuts and tahini-lime dressing (above). Make that this weekend, or Judy Kim’s chile oil noodles with cilantro, Melissa Clark’s eggplant focaccia with ricotta and olives or any of the recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Trump Ads Attack Biden Through Deceptive Editing and Hyperbole
description: We reviewed all of the Trump campaign’s television ads since June. Two-thirds contained clearly misleading claims or videos.
content: President Trump’s re-election campaign has spent tens of millions of dollars on television ads attacking his Democratic opponent, Joseph R. Biden Jr. While their content varies greatly, be it the coronavirus, police funding, taxes or charter schools, the tactics used remain constant: selectively edited remarks and exaggerations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Astor
title: Aritana Yawalapiti, Revered Indigenous Leader in Brazil, Dies at 71
description: Known for his quiet dignity, he dedicated himself to protecting the environment and promoting the health of his people. He died of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Mahajan
title: Doris Lessing’s ‘Golden Notebook’ and Our Era of Unrest
description: Lessing’s 1962 novel is far from a manifesto. But in its embrace of chaos and split identities, it captures the mood of both its time and ours.
content: When Doris Lessing, the British-Zimbabwean novelist who died in 2013, sat down to write “The Golden Notebook” in the 1950s, she was responding to a feeling of defeat in leftist circles, one similar to the whiplash experienced by liberals after the election of President Trump. The marquee intellectual philosophy of the young 20th century — communism — was sagging from the revelation that “Father Stalin” had overseen the death of millions; communist stalwarts in the West, like Lessing, felt they’d had the carpet pulled out from under them. They became intellectually homeless. Meanwhile, Senator Joseph McCarthy was raving like a proto-Trump at left-leaning Americans. What had this generation’s progressive causes amounted to?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater, Jack Healy, Michael D. Shear and Hailey Fuchs
title: Postal Crisis Ripples Across Nation as Election Looms
description: President Trump’s furious objection to mail-in balloting and a new Trump-allied postmaster general are raising fears about the election and the Postal Service.
content: DARBY, Pa. — Each day, when Nick Casselli, the president of a Philadelphia postal workers union, sits down at his desk on Main Street in this historic town where trolley cars still run and the post office is a source of civic pride, his phone is full of alarmed messages about increasing delays in mail delivery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: A Dictatorship in Belarus Is Shaken
description: It seems that those living under Aleksandr Lukashenko’s rule won’t abide him forever.
content: For a quarter of a century now, Aleksandr Lukashenko has been offering a master class in dictatorship in Belarus, the country he runs with an iron hand. But after the blatantly rigged election of Aug. 9, the next lesson should be in how dictatorships are brought to an end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Bald Eagle Sends Government Drone Into Lake Michigan
description: A Michigan state environmental agency, which is abbreviated E.G.L.E., lost a $950 drone in the aerial battle.
content: A squabble in the sky over Lake Michigan left one bald eagle victorious and one government drone mangled and sunken.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 15, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 15, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about the promotion of a theory by President Trump that questions Senator Kamala Harris’s eligibility to run for vice president misspelled the name of the University of California school from which Ms. Harris’s parents received doctorates. It was the University of California, Berkeley, not Berkley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Looking Behind Trump’s Latest Attack on Canada’s Aluminum Exports
description: We spoke with an economist in Washington about the U.S. president’s latest trade salvo against his neighboring trade partner.
content: That didn’t take long. The new trade deal between Canada, the United States and Mexico was barely a month old when President Trump, during a tour of a Whirlpool appliance factory, announced that he’d again placed tariffs on aluminum from Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel L. Harris
title: ‘Kamala Harris’s Nomination Is Everything to Me’
description: For some, the senator’s being on the Democratic ticket is about more than just the vice presidency.
content: Joe Biden’s selection of Senator Kamala Harris to be his running mate is historic. She is the first Black woman and the first person of Indian descent to be on a major-party ticket and, should Biden win, stands that much closer to becoming the first female president in our nation’s history. It’s no surprise that many Americans are emotional about her being chosen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The 19th Amendment: An Important Milestone in an Unfinished Journey
description: A century later, it’s past time to recognize the women of color who were sidelined in the fight for gender and racial equality.
content: Historians who specialize in voting rights and African-American women’s history have played a welcome and unusually public role in combating the myths that have long surrounded the women’s suffrage movement and the 19th Amendment, which celebrates its 100th anniversary on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Levey Friedman
title: The Improbable Journey of the Suffragist Sash
description: How a strip of fabric went from iconic protest accessory to pageant queen prop to bachelorette party wear.
content: A sash — a piece of fabric draped over the head and worn from the shoulder to the opposite hip — is a strange garment. Its purpose is, essentially, decorative, but it has been worn for decoration by many types: It was part of male military dress uniforms in Europe at least as long ago as the 16th century. Royalty make use of them as well — you may recall that at his 2011 wedding, Prince William wore a bright blue sash with his dress uniform, and Princess Grace of Monaco frequently appeared in hers, an Order of St. Charles band.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Jamieson
title: The Music and the Mirror
description: In Hope Larson’s graphic novel “All Together Now,” an eighth-grade singer-songwriter struggles to find her voice after the band she started breaks up.
content: Garage bands, first kisses, broken friendships; it’s a winning combination. ALL TOGETHER NOW (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 192 pp., $12.99; ages 10 to 14), from the acclaimed comics creator Hope Larson, tackles all these topics and more in a story that feels fresh, and will be immediately relatable to a middle grade audience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: ‘You’re a Warrior’: Vanessa Guillen Is Memorialized
description: The family of the Army specialist, whose remains were recovered after being reported missing for months from Fort Hood in Texas, remembered her on Friday at a service at her high school.
content: A horse-drawn carriage took a coffin decorated with Mexican and American flags of the slain Army Specialist Vanessa Guillen for one last lap on her high school’s track field on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruchir Sharma
title: People Aren’t Reading or Watching Movies. They’re Gaming.
description: During the pandemic, digital three-dimensional environments are where much of life is taking place.
content: Even before the pandemic and the lockdowns, digital games were fast emerging as one of the world’s favorite pastimes. But when live entertainment came to a halt, the virtual kind just took off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Kornei
title: How Do You Solve a Moon Mystery? Fire a Laser at It
description: Researchers have used reflective prisms left on the moon’s surface for decades, but had increasingly seen problems with their effectiveness.
content: The moon is drifting away. Every year, it gets about an inch and a half farther from us. Hundreds of millions of years from now, our companion in the sky will be distant enough that there will be no more total solar eclipses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Damian Lillard Gets Help Moving Portland Out of the Yacht Club
description: With a fourth quarter scoring run propelled by CJ McCollum and Carmelo Anthony, Portland earned a spot in the first round of the N.B.A. playoffs. They will face LeBron James’s Lakers.
content: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — The N.B.A. and the league’s television partners did not get their dream first-round playoff matchup pitting LeBron James and the Los Angeles Lakers against Zion Williamson and the New Orleans Pelicans. The solace for those parties is that the fallback option will offer no shortage of offensive flammability and star power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik, Reggie Ugwu, Maya Phillips and Julia Jacobs
title: When Trump Calls a Black Woman ‘Angry,’ He Feeds This Racist Trope
description: President Trump’s use of the word to describe Joe Biden’s vice-presidential pick, Kamala Harris, plays off a hurtful stereotype with a decades-long history.
content: Kamala Harris may become the first Black woman elected as vice president, but for now she’s still being slotted into a well-worn mold, as President Trump and his allies seek to cast her as “a mad woman.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan North
title: Bone Up on Shakespeare, With a Skeleton and His Ankle-Nibbling Nemesis
description: Jeremy and Hermione Tankard’s “Yorick and Bones: The Last Graphic Novel by William Shakespeare” is poignant tickle-your-ribs entertainment.
content: This charming spoof purports to be a long-lost work for younger readers by the Bard of Avon himself. But the reality of YORICK AND BONES: The Last Graphic Novel by William Shakespeare (HarperAlley, 144 pp., $16.99; ages 8 to 12), and its own secret origin, is even more charming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater, Hailey Fuchs and Nick Corasaniti
title: The Postal Service warns states it may not meet mail-in ballot deadlines.
description: The Postal Service has warned states that it may not be able to meet their deadlines for delivering last-minute mail-in ballots, further fueling the clash over the new postmaster general’s handling of vote-by-mail operations as President Trump continues to rail against the practice.
content: The Postal Service has warned states that it may not be able to meet their deadlines for delivering last-minute mail-in ballots, further fueling the clash over the new postmaster general’s handling of vote-by-mail operations as President Trump continues to rail against the practice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo
title: Spend Your Week With Bach, Beowulf and a Bee Aficionado
description: Check out emerging New York photographers, stitch up a suffragist’s portrait and liven up your lunch break with a digital dance party.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Under Siege in Belarus, Lukashenko Turns to Putin
description: The shift toward Russia comes at a time of crisis for President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus, who has frequently played Moscow off against the West.
content: MOSCOW — After claiming for weeks that Russia was plotting to overthrow him, President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus appealed to the Kremlin on Saturday for help against a wave of protests and strikes triggered by police violence after a disputed presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Courtney Rubin
title: Dealing With the Freshman Down the Hall
description: For many students this fall, “college” will be their childhood bedroom or family dining room. Here’s how parents can help make the experience easier for everyone.
content: Every day, it seems, another college abandons in-person plans in favor of starting the fall semester online. Along with the crushing disappointment, first-year students now have to navigate the transition to college without the accompanying freedom of leaving home. And parents may face behaviors and habits — sleeping until noon, skipping class — they wouldn’t see if the student were away at school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: How to Save the Europa League
description: UEFA might have (accidentally) landed on the perfect model for its second-tier championship, a way to make it distinctive and special and, yes, valuable.
content: You could have been enjoying this newsletter yesterday. If you like it, sign up to get it directly, every Friday, at nytimes.com/rory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Trump refrains from disavowing QAnon conspiracy.
description: President Trump on Friday refused to disavow the QAnon conspiracy theory, avoiding questions from a reporter about whether he agreed with Marjorie Taylor Greene, the Republican nominee for a House seat in Georgia, in her support of a movement that has been labeled a potential domestic terrorism threat by the F.B.I.
content: President Trump on Friday refused to disavow the QAnon conspiracy theory, avoiding questions from a reporter about whether he agreed with Marjorie Taylor Greene, the Republican nominee for a House seat in Georgia, in her support of a movement that has been labeled a potential domestic terrorism threat by the F.B.I.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. School District Cancels Classes After Teacher ‘Sick Out’ Over Virus Fears
description: South Korea warns of another outbreak tied to a church. Mitt Romney blasts President Trump’s handling of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Harlan
title: Join the Final Drive To Suffrage
description: Our game lets you follow the 19th Amendment’s journey from passage in the Senate to ratification by 36 states.
content: On June 4, 1919, the Susan B. Anthony Amendment came before the Senate. It was the fifth time that the proposal — first introduced in 1878, and already approved by the House of Representatives — had been put to senators; four months earlier, it had fallen short by just one vote. But on this day, the federal lawmakers voted 56 to 25, to pass the law, amend the constitution and establish women’s right to vote in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

title: If You Were Kamala Harris’s Campaign Adviser …
description: We asked readers what advice they would give her and got more than 1,600 responses, sometimes contradictory (be an “attack dog,” avoid “personal attacks”). Some found the request sexist.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: An Order Might Be One
description: Joe DiPietro marches us around on the weekend.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Belly up to the bar, guys! Joe DiPietro is back with his first Saturday grid in over three years, and his establishment, the “one star” bar, is doing business in Chelsea. Drop by and tell him what you thought of his puns!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: James R. Thompson, Longest-Serving Governor of Illinois, Dies at 84
description: A relentless campaigner, he served for 14 years after winning an election to a special two-year term in 1976.
content: James R. Thompson, a Republican known as Big Jim who used his enthusiasm for campaigning and his canny understanding of state politics to become the longest-serving governor of Illinois, died on Friday. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Gold
title: The British Monarchy Is a Game. Harry and Meghan Didn’t Want to Play.
description: Prince Harry confused sacrifice with service. Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, confused it with fame.
content: What is required of the British monarchy?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Can Co-ops Fine Residents for Not Wearing Masks?
description: Some buildings are playing hardball when it comes to enforcing pandemic rules. But how much power do they really have?
content: Q: I live in a co-op in Riverdale. Building management has sent out several notices requesting that residents wear masks at all times when in the common areas of the buildings. But the co-op took it a step further, writing an email threatening to assess fines to any resident who fails to comply with the requirements. Does the co-op have the authority to assess fines for failure to wear masks?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Georgia Trooper Is Charged in Fatal Shooting of Black Driver
description: The trooper, who is white, was fired and charged with murder a week after the killing, which happened after the driver had been pulled over for having a broken taillight, the authorities said.
content: A Georgia state trooper was fired and charged with murder on Friday, one week after a 60-year-old Black man was fatally shot during a traffic stop over a broken taillight on his car, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Alternative Cinema
description: Francis Heaney’s the summer blockbuster this year.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — The days are getting shorter and I was beginning to worry that we wouldn’t get a Sunday puzzle with a movie theme. This is a weird year for film buffs! I know that streaming services were affecting attendance long before 2020, but there were still plenty of movie theaters that employed popcorn poppers, projectionists and ushers, and I have fond memories of going to a movie during a New York summer like this one just to freeze myself for a couple of hours and recalibrate my feelings toward torrid heat. I worry now about those places and the people who made them run. On the other hand, I know that many of us have probably knocked rafts of movies off our watch lists, and there are new summer movies that went straight to the small screen, so cinematic life goes on, even if it’s limping at the moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: A Bitter Wind at a Shaky Time, and Iowa Is Left Reeling
description: Devastating windstorms just before harvest were the last thing that Iowa farmers needed.
content: As the winds howled outside, gusting at over 100 miles per hour, families hid in their basements and wondered what would await them when they emerged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Keenan
title: Barred From a Confederate Shrine, Protesters Scuffle in Georgia
description: Far-right groups hoping to rally at Stone Mountain were thwarted when the park was closed, and were met with counterprotests in a town where some would rather bridge racial divides than widen them.
content: STONE MOUNTAIN, Ga. — A small city in the Atlanta suburbs and the big, contentious Confederate monument that shares its name seemed headed for trouble on Saturday. Far-right activists and white supremacist militia groups planned to gather at Stone Mountain to symbolically “defend” the monument, and antiracist and far-left counterprotesters planned to confront them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Trump Officially Orders TikTok’s Chinese Owner to Divest
description: The president, who last week gave ByteDance 45 days to sell its stake or else face U.S. restrictions, added a 90-day deadline under a national security law.
content: President Trump doubled down late Friday on his previous actions against TikTok by formally giving ByteDance, the Chinese owner of the popular video-sharing app, 90 days to divest from its American assets and any data that TikTok had gathered in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Biden Dreams of Kamelot
description: Trumpworld dismisses Harris as calculating. But we need a woman who can calculate a way out of the mess this president has made.
content: WASHINGTON — One wintry day in 1992, my boss drolly told me to try to look young.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Senior
title: Learning to Love Joe Biden
description: He’s not out on the campaign trail now, but when he was a young man in a hurry, he told us who he was.
content: There’s a reason that a certain kind of journalist makes a quadrennial habit of reading “What It Takes,” Richard Ben Cramer’s gonzo classic about the 1988 presidential primary. It’s catnip to prose snobs. It’s a New Journalism masterpiece, freckled with ellipses, popping with sound effects. And it shows, better than perhaps any campaign book in the last half-century, what metabolically and psychologically distinguishes those who seek the presidency from those who consider eight nonspectacular hours at their day jobs triumph enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.C. Shilton
title: Don’t Wait to Deck Out Your Back Porch
description: The pandemic has many people thinking about how they’ll spend time outside as the weather cools, meaning favorites items may soon be in short supply.
content: Toilet paper notwithstanding, the best thing Todd Osterman did back in April was start thinking about how to furnish his patio. But really, “my wife was the one who was thinking way ahead,” the Wisconsin teacher said. “She was the one who thought this might be a long-term thing.” If they were going to be home all summer, they might as well enjoy their patio — which meant getting a heater for those early-spring nights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: A Summer of No-Contact Rescues: How Lifeguards Have Changed Their Ways
description: Guards have tested positive. After-work parties are frowned upon. The pandemic has upended lifeguarding.
content: The Avalon Beach Patrol, on the New Jersey shore, is an elite lifeguard corps that holds tryouts each year, dominates in lifesaving competitions and prides itself on protecting swimmers from treacherous ocean conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Boys State’ and ‘Platonic’
description: Catch this engaging political documentary, and a series about dating in pre-pandemic New York City.
content: BOYS STATE (2020) Stream on Apple TV+. Every year, hundreds of high-school-aged boys in Texas head to Austin for a weeklong mock government exercise known as Boys State. In 2018, the married filmmakers Jesse Moss and Amanda McBaine embedded in the fray, following four of the participants as their parties drafted platforms and elected key officials, including a governor. In the process, the filmmakers capture a hopeful demonstration of democracy that also reflects the hyper-polarized tensions of politics today. In her New York Times review, Manohla Dargis wrote that “the filmmakers have made an engaging movie about some kids who — as their jokes give way to debates, stratagems and even shocks — already seem to be drafting their own more interesting sequel.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Sergey Ponomarev
title: ‘The Fish Rots From the Head’: How a Salmon Crisis Stoked Russian Protests
description: Plentiful salmon used to be one of the few perks for residents of Russia’s Far East. Then the fish vanished, and many local residents blamed President Putin.
content: OZERPAKH, Russia — A row of stakes hundreds of feet long pokes out of the endless estuary of the Amur River on Russia’s Pacific coast, resembling the naked spine of a giant fish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman
title: An expected guilty plea in the review of the Russia inquiry pleases Trump.
description: A former F.B.I. lawyer intends to plead guilty after he was charged with falsifying a document as part of a deal with prosecutors conducting their own criminal inquiry of the Russia investigation, according to his lawyer and court documents made public on Friday.
content: A former F.B.I. lawyer intends to plead guilty after he was charged with falsifying a document as part of a deal with prosecutors conducting their own criminal inquiry of the Russia investigation, according to his lawyer and court documents made public on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon take a prismatic tone with us.
content: ACROSTIC — Today’s excerpt is from a modern American classic, “Song of Solomon,” a 1977 novel by Toni Morrison, who later became the first African-American woman to win the Nobel Prize in Literature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: Kamala Harris, Daughter of Immigrants, Is the Face of America’s Demographic Shift
description: Her parents’ arrival to Berkeley as young graduate students was the beginning of a historic wave of immigration from outside Europe that would change the United States in ways its leaders never imagined.
content: When Kamala Harris’s mother left India for California in 1958, the percentage of Americans who were immigrants was at its lowest point in over a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Lights Dim and Worries Mount as a Heat Wave Roasts California
description: Overwhelmed by demand, California’s power grid imposed rotating blackouts, while the coronavirus crisis created a dilemma for those who were unable to stay cool at home.
content: A heat wave rolling through the Southwest has forced intermittent power shut-offs in California, a state already struggling with wildfires and a recent surge in coronavirus cases, raising fears that the rising temperatures could turn deadly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Protesters Gather Outside Postmaster General’s Home
description: Demonstrators say changes recently made by Postmaster General Louis DeJoy, a major donor to Trump campaigns, undercut the Postal Service and threaten Americans’ right to vote.
content: Demonstrators say changes recently made by Postmaster General Louis DeJoy, a major donor to Trump campaigns, undercut the Postal Service and threaten Americans’ right to vote.
source.name: The New York Times
